description:
Cell phone sized red-white-and-green striped rectangle markings on middle of street posts, light posts.  Delicious smell of pizza everywhere. This is how we accidentally discovered it, ventured into it.  Little Italy, San Francisco.  Italian flag signs.  http://www.sftodo.com/sanfrancisco/north-beach-little-italy

This architecturally interesting corner of Grant Ave and Broadway, diagonally cut by Columbus Ave, making triangle of streets, east coast European style triangle-shaped building at corner.  One of those neighborhoods where restaurants and shops are on the 1st floor of buildings and the top floors can be converted into apartment homes or artist lofts, separate entrance, view of the city.  

I want to live here.  I always liked San Francisco but I want to live here.  North Beach/Russian Hill.  Centrally located between Chinatown and Pier 39, walking distance to City Lights Bookstore.  

Charming and lively neighborhood.  People out and about, walking on sidewalk, sitting in outdoor cafes, European tourists and locals, visiting triathlon athletes (  http://www.escapealcatraztri.com/news/2017/2018-escape-from-alcatraz-triathlon-returns-to-san-francisco-on-june-3  ), bicyclists and rented scooters, Saturay evening turning into night.  
https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/networth/article/Electric-scooters-for-grown-ups-now-available-for-12786451.php

Parking nearly impossible, hilly streets of San Francisco.  Parked near Chinatown $8, walking distance.  

In search of "Cioppino," Italian seafood soup that originated in USA, San Francisco.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cioppino   But wait!!  Pizza sounds soooooooo good, too!  Well, you can have both!  We're in Little Italy, San Francisco, afterall.  Several restaurants to choose from, picked the one with better Yelp ratings, classic Italian Renaissance restaurant, art paintings on ceiling, greco-roman bust statues, celebrity pics on wall, waitstaff with Italian accents, table behind us, visiting French couple tourists whose wine was not to their liking-they ordered a different one, TV screen, Gold State Warriors basketball game ... because it's the 2018 NBA Western Conference playoffs. .... http://www.nba.com/warriors  
  We're not in Kansas anymore.  We're in NorCal, not L.A. Laker Land. Cioppino delicious! But at $45, would've liked crab legs but menu offered no options for that.  Pizza diablo hot and spicy but devishly good!

Would love to come back to Little Italy, San Francisco and try each and every one of those wonderful restaurants, cafes, gourmet markets and deli's, coffee houses, gelato and desserts, and inviting shops and stores, businesses that reflect the warm fun loving people of the neighborhood.
author: Suzee L.

description:
North Beach is just one of the best places to walk around and enjoy.  Coffee, food, cuisine (different then food HA!), ambiance, the park, the church, the small businesses in the side streets ........ etc.

Nice thing about North Beach (NB) is the location: Chinatown, Lombard Street, and Fisherman's Wharf surround NB with Little Italy smack dap in the middle of NB.  Walking is the best way to see SF in this area.  OR Use the bus line to get here from the Financial District or from Powell St.

If there is one hidden-gem for SF is North Beach.  Once you visit, you will know why.  This place gets a 5-Star because it truly is As Good As It Gets!
author: Randy L.

description:
"Little Italy" is the name many call the district of North Beach. Like some have mentioned at one time this was actually a beach before the development of San Francisco in the 1800's. The Barbary Coast! Essentially it came down to property value, and land is worth more money than ocean, honey, so humankind of the 19th century rearranged the coast to create what we know today. And we wonder why seals crawl all over the piers! 

Despite human intervention the district of North Beach is one of my favorites in the city. Main intersections are Union & Columbus, the southwest corner of Washington Square, Grant Avenue & Vallejo Street. I love the rich history, the cluster of victorian buildings, the Italian Restaurants, pizzerias, gelato shops, bakeries, euro-inspired coffee cafes, and even the sexiness of the Italian Athletic Club that has been there a century before the legendary Italian Stallion (visions of a young Stallone). 

The history is rich with Italian tradition hence the popular "Little Italy". I mean you'll see more green, red, white colors here than you'll find in Naples. Back in the day, the DiMaggio brothers would practice playing wiffle ball in the streets, led by baseball legend, Joe DiMaggio. Dominic was the goofy brother, but still good enough to make it to the big leagues. There's even a Christopher Columbus statue in the area, the famous Italian explorer who was actually of Spanish blood, alas my love, Antonio Banderas wouldn't mind. 

I adore Little Italy where I can wear my Italian flag proudly while riding my classic Lambretta, Armani snuggly on, bouffant flapping in the wind. I love the Stinking Rose, Roma Coffee, and a Clean Well Lighted Books on the corner are some of my favorites. Ahhh that's amore! 

"don't want a boy
I've got a man of steel
Don't come any closer
I don't wanna feel, OOH!
Your breathing, your touching
But nothing's for free
I never want this to happen to me
Don't try to change me you're wasting your time
Now I've got something much better in mind

Robert De Niro's waiting
Talking Italian
Robert De Niro's waiting
Talking Italian
Robert De Niro's waiting
Talking Italian (Talking Italian)
Robert De Niro's waiting..."
author: Eric R.

description: Our group had an amazing experience with dinner at North Beach. Parking was a nightmare but after circling for 10min, I accepted defeat and went with their $10 valet. For our large group of 18, they turned their downstairs kitchen into and dining room under their salted/peppered prosciutto which hangs from the ceiling. It was an interesting and kitchy addition to our overall dining experience. Good thing none of our guests were vegan! The meal options were preset and we could choose from a few different menus with varying price points. We went with menu#3 including chicken parm, eggplant parm, and halibut all paired with white and red wines. Starters included bread, focaccia, oil and vinegar, and a melon prosciutto plate, with tiramisu for dessert. It was a fabulous dinner, with amazing customer service, attentive wait staff, and charming environment!
author: Araceli C.

description:
North Beach is losing it's charm!!!

Kaps Corner ... gone.  Bocce's ... died a long slow death.  Steps of Rome ... gone.  Stinking Rose ... going down hill.  Many of the old time bars are threatened.  Victoria Pastry is still around but lost their original spot (by choice but still).

This used to be my favorite neighborhood in all of the Bay Area.  Accessible by BART.  Centrally located so friends from all over (East Bay, SF, Peninsula) can easily meet.

It still has some good low end options like Golden Boy Pizza and high end options like North Beach Restaurant.  And bars like Specs and Vesuvios are kicking it "old school".  A walk in the early evening up Columbus to Washington Square is a must do.  

But a lot the mid-tier restaurants, mentioned above, are waning.

North Beach, unlike China Town, is not really a living neighborhood any more.  Many of the 2nd and 3rd generation Italians don't live there nor go into the family business.  Old North Beach is still there, but it's harder to find.
author: Joe G.

description:
Who rated this less than 5 Stars?  This is the Old School SF Neighborhood that is Beautiful.  Come if you haven't been.

I would contend that this is one of the coolest neighborhoods in America.  It's Little Italy, California-Style.  North Beach is not north of a beach.  It used to be.  Now, it's a fun neighborhood to hang out, eat and drink.  And, many other things.

Adam S.'s Top 10 North Beach List:

10.  Bacon Wrapped Tater Tots.  The Boardroom made it happen and it will soon be upgrading to even nicer digs.  A great bar and grill.  
9.  Vallejo Street Steps.  You can walk up the side of Russian Hill and get some great views.  Stop by Ina Coolbrith Park (named after the first documented Caucasian female to come to pre-SF SF).  Great views, especially on a clear day.
8.  Proximity to Chinatown.  You can cover a lot of culture quick.  Apropos since Morco Polo brought pasta back from the Orient.
7.  Take the Cannoli.  I like the Dark Chocolate Orange Cannoli at Alimento.  Many people like Mara or Victoria.   There's plenty of good Cannoli. 
6.  Coit Tower.  Looks like a Fire Hose.  Named after Little Lillie Coit, who has a big fan of the firefighters that saved SF after the 1906 Earthquake.  
5.  The Saloon.  A great venue for Live Music that was saved because it used to be a brothel in 1906 that a lot of firefighters frequented.  Thus, one of the oldest bars in SF.  
4.  People Watching.  Just Watch.  You'll See.
3.  Golden Boy Pizza.  OMG.  There is nothing like this place.  Look for the finger pointing down at the trays  of Pizza in the Window.  Smell the Smell.  Partake.
2.  Caffe Trieste.  Or, some of the other Old School stuff.  I like Caffe Trieste.  I'm a big Cafe au Lait guy. 
1.  Washington Square Park.  Some Day, this will go down as the last great town square in America.  I feel like I am in the world of the Greek and Roman Gods.
author: Adam S.

description: Oh North Beach. You have called me to your door! How I can linger on the words of Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg..don't forget Diane Di Prima. I love this part of town. How you can have a cannoli from Stella's, stop by City Lights for a reading, walk along Columbus, go to Cobb's for some comedy by a real celebrity comedian, Bimbo's for some indie, eat Indian at Kennedy's Irish pub, and don't forget a slice of pizza!!! Is there any more legendary Little Italy in the world? But no more sighting of Italians and beatniks these days...you'll have more luck with the tourists...
author: Denise C.

description: A restaurant has to be extraordinary to get 5 stars when it is as expensive (wow expensive) as North Beach.  North Beach absolutely qualifies as extraordinary.  The food is spectacular, hands down the best I have had at any Italian restaurant, even in NYC.  But the best part of North Beach is the service.  Our waiter was the epitome of everything I hope for.  His recommendations were professional and not pushy; his attention was steady without being imposing; he was always a step ahead of what was needed at the table.  There is a reason this place has been in business so long, and the reason is excellence in everything they do.
author: Frank B.

description: Traditional Italian and served with top notch service and upscale ambiance.  What more could you want?  Hands down, this is by far the best in my opinion!
author: Anita T.

description:
One of San Francisco's best neighborhoods. But do not under any circumstances Dr. If you've got a car park at one of the main parking garages in Union Square or on Market Street, walk, or take over.

This neighborhood is quintessential San Francisco on steroids, but it doesn't feel touristy. Restaurants and people are authentic. Food is amazing. Prices can be reasonable if you know where to look. There's chocolate, there's Italian food, there's ice cream, there's drinking, there's people watching, there's even a nativity scene on Christmas.
author: scott h.

description:
I came for the prosciutto and melon.....again. And again. Old schooly charm overcomes the weaker pasta menu, but the pounded veal is great and the wine selection is great. Watch out for what they charge on the bottles since the up charge is pretty steep if you are familiar with the vintage. If not, relax and enjoy. Outside seating is not bad and the service is always right on. 
The frozen drink is a must no matter what the weather.
author: David B.

description:
Ahh North Beach or Little Italy depending on who you are talking with.   It's between China Town and Fisherman's Wharf.

It's a nice neighborhood to explore.  It doesn't feel as touristy as the grand Street in China Town or Fisherman's Wharf.

I usually get a pastry at one of the bakaries and there are also great shops, bars and restaurants.  

Don't miss the big white church.  It's hosted famous weddings.    It's just a great area to take a break from the tourist rush.
author: Mark B.

description:
Oh North Beach, how I adore you, you provide me with so many places to eat, drink and have fun at. The possibilities are kinda endless here. That is why North Beach will be my "150th" review and "3rd" milestone review that involves The City of San Francisco or a landmark in or around the city. Plus I'm here every other Sunday if not every Sunday. So that should be a testament of how much I like this place. North Beach is where it's at, and let me brag a little about why....

2 - 28 - 2016
Getting ready for my usual SF nightlife activities. I had to stop and think to myself...."why haven't I did a review of a place that I like to visit so much? Well now is better than never right? So as my slogan says "I took one bart train, and later stopped at a bar and had my two shots" Sorces say, that after you walk past the Transamerica Building you officially step into "Little Italy" or "The Church of Scientology" and for the record....they are annoying people trying to get you to take a survey or sorts..moving along. Before you cross the street after the Transamerica building, you would see the first street post at the end of Montgomery where the lamppost is adorned with the signiture "Italian Flag" also letting you know that you have made it to the right place. Also where Montgomery turn into my favorite street (aside from Broadway) Columbus Street!

North Beach is home to the North Beach towers which sit on Kerney St and aside from the "Little Italy" aspect that North Beach is known for, lets not forget that Asian influence and Irish influence here as well, with that being said Chinatown SF and Irish Section (I don't know if that is the proper term) is here as well, and trust me....I've made my mark at those spots respectivly. North Beach is the part of SF that I feel has a lot to offer anyone that happens to come and visit, you have those down home places, and those posh places if that happens to be your thang! (yes I said thang instead of saying thing) "Everyday is a Weekend Here" my bartender @ Grant and Green (off Grant and Green Streets) told me. Here you would find aside from the bars and lounges and fantastic little eateries, nice little art studios and trendy clothing shops, coffee and boba joints and old churches and sightseeing galore here oh and if you're really wanting to get a nice view of SF....the Coit Tower is located in North Beach as well.  

Let me break it down to you a little by what you would find on some of the streets here..

Kerney St - Here you would find some of those seedy massage parlors and little oriental shops and such that didn't make it in Chinatown, also at the end of the street you would find Larry Flints Hustler Club right before you hit the redlight district which is called....

Broadway Street - Well I have to say, I have two dukedoms here at two places....The Condor and Penthouse SF, and yes they are Gentelmens Clubs. Hey don't judge me, they are fun places! Deja Vu Centerfolds, Garden of Eden and the Hungry Eye are also on this street, yea you have all the fake ballers and wanna be pimps that walk up and down this street, but if you wanna dance and not get a lapdance per say :D You have Hue Nightclub (formerly Atmostphere Ultra Lounge) and Monroe Lounge that would provide you with a night of calorie burning and drunken fun also instagram memes. Let's not forget Noc Noc on Broadway and Bamboo Hut is located here if you want to drink something intresting but if not you also have..

Grant St - Now this is where I think you would find the Bar, Saloon, Pub, or Lounge of your dreams and me of course! this is my go too street when i'm here. When you see the "Gold or sometimes Silver Chains and Yankees Hat" you would know that you've spotted me and in that case....don't be afraid to say hello and have a shot with me! anywho, Grant and Green, Tope, Maggie McGarry's, The Saloon Blues Bar, Tupelo and other drinking establishments adorn this street, and you can't sometimes leave this street without being sober, i'm guilty most of the time i'm here, but if you wanna eat then you must visit the main street..

Columbus Street - Here you would find that this street is like the official connection to all the hotspots here in North Beach, The Stinking Rose, Busters Cheesesteak, Taqueria Zorro, Yan's Chinese Kitchen, and Pizzelle di North Beach and let's not forget Molinari Delicatessen all sit on this street, it's like....impossible to walk on this street and not get hungry and that is only half of what's here, I still haven't named everything else but you have to see for yourself.

In closing, if you come here make sure you have some money to spend (or throw if you hang on broadway) you will need it for the Food, the Drinks, and the Uber or Lyft ride home or BART fair, because here you will indeed eat, drink and have a good time! As always Yelp your own experiences and opinions and Check In! I already have dukedom battles going on here! :D
author: Tre S.

description:
North Beach is a neighborhood in San Francisco I've grown familiar with because one of my good friends used to live nearby, specifically, in Telegraph Hill (he's since moved to Russian Hill, so still in the same vicinity). In recent years, every time I visited the Bay Area, I'd always make it out to North Beach and we'd walk around, whether to a park, pier, bookstore, pub, cafe, or gelato shop, and hang out. This, like many other parts of San Francisco, is a cool area.

The neighborhood is popular with both tourists and locals. The touristy areas are to the north towards Fisherman's Wharf and the piers, along the Embarcadero (with cruises to Alcatraz), in the center where Coit Tower is located, and along the western and southern edges where the neighborhood borders Russian Hill (Lombard Street), Chinatown, and the Financial District (downtown). Even though the neighborhood doesn't touch any water, North Beach got its name because it used to be an actual beach. It's since been filled with landfill.

Because of all the hills, there are great vistas of the city in all directions. The best places for views and photos are at and around Coit Tower and facing southward down one of the main drags, Columbus Ave, into the Financial District. The higher elevation you are, the better, of course. Filbert St, near Coit Tower, is one of the steepest streets in the city measuring in at 17.5 degrees (31.5% grade). For those not used to the steepness of the streets, they can be terrifying to drive and park on.

The southeastern part of North Beach around Telegraph Hill sits above the Financial District. Columbus Ave feeds directly into the Transamerica Pyramid, San Francisco's iconic and tallest skyscraper. Speaking of Columbus, there are a lot of things to see and do at Columbus and Broadway. North Beach is known as San Francisco's Little Italy and there are numerous Italian restaurants and pizza joints in the vicinity. Not only that, but the area is known for its nightlife, littered in numerous bars and nightclubs, many with live entertainment. Most notably, at least as has been pointed out to me multiple times by different people, The Condor, which is supposedly the world's first topless and bottomless strip club. Oh yeah.

Off the top of my head, a few good memories of places I've enjoyed and recommend in North Beach include:

* Walking around Washington Square Park (http://www.yelp.com/biz/washington-square-park-san-francisco)
* Grabbing pizza at North Beach Pizza (http://www.yelp.com/biz/north-beach-pizza-san-francisco-6)
* Indulging at Gelato Classico Italian (http://www.yelp.com/biz/gelato-classico-italian-san-francisco)
* Eating garlicky food at The Stinking Rose (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-stinking-rose-a-garlic-restaurant-san-francisco)
* Checking out the historic City Lights Bookstore (http://www.yelp.com/biz/city-lights-bookstore-san-francisco)

And while this place is technically not within North Beach boundaries, I highly recommend checking out Union Street Produce Company (http://www.yelp.com/biz/union-street-produce-company-san-francisco) for fresh produce, juices, and basic grocery store needs. The store is located just one block west of North Beach on Union St at Mason St.

Finally, see if you can spot the wild parrots on the Filbert Steps (http://www.yelp.com/biz/filbert-steps-san-francisco) and check out The Saloon (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-saloon-san-francisco), San Francisco's oldest bar with live music and well-priced drinks. Have a good time.
author: Daniel B.

description:
"LITTLE ITALY" MY FAVORITE DISTRICT OF SAN FRANCISCO

I was born in San Francisco but I moved to the East Bay when I was two years old. I'm not an expert in San Francisco far from it. Ever since I graduated from college I have been working in the Financial District of San Francisco. I've never worked full time outside of San Francisco. Throughout the years I visited certain parts of San Francisco. There are several districts in San Francisco that have their own unique flavor. Chinatown is the largest Chinese community of China. The Mission District has Latin influence through its eateries and street food stands. The Financial District, where I work, is the business hub in the city. Of all the districts my favorite is North Beach.

There's something about North Beach that attracts locals and tourists alike. As you walk in Columbus Avenue and head toward Broadway you see the Beats influence through City Lights Bookstore. Feel naughty? On Broadway you can feel the seedy environment through the strip club and adult entertainment. Want to feel holy? There are two churches are in North Beach. The first is the Saint Francis of Assisi National Shrine. That church isn't a practicing church however the patron saint for of San Francisco is Saint Francis. The second church in North Beach is the Saints Peter and Paul Catholic Church that situates on Washington Park and conducts services in several languages. Want a quick bite to eat? Then go to Golden Boy Pizza where locals flock to eat a Sicilian-style pizza with its foccacia bread crust. Ever inspire to be a writer? Have a sip of espresso at Caffè Trieste where Francis Ford Coppola wrote the script for "The Godfather". 

People mostly go to North Beach to eat at the Italian restaurants hence why North Beach is referred as "Little Italy". These restaurants don't feature just Italian food. What makes these restaurant charming is that each restaurant specializes in their own regional cuisine whether they are Roman, Tuscan, Neapolitan, or Sicilian. (On my profile I created a list titled North Beach Eating - Italian Regional Cuisine Restaurants). The blending of different regional cultures from the same country is another example why San Francisco is considered a melting pot. When I see Italian restaurants struggling on shows such as Kitchen Nightmares or Restaurant Impossible I feel like either the owner or manager of those restaurants should come to North Beach to see how Italian restaurants thrive. It is stated that San Francisco is the most European city in this country. I've been to Europe and when you eat at one of those Italian restaurants along Columbus Avenue it is reminiscent of eating at cafés in Europe. 

The food scene at North Beach while maintaining its identity is also evolving. One example is fine dining as Michelin Star restaurants such as Gary Danko, Quince, and Coi are located in North Beach. In fact Coi is located close to a strip club. Where else can you find a fine dining restaurant next adult entertainment? That's why you have to love North Beach.

I heard that North Beach in the 1970s was rough and tough. If you ever saw "Dirty Harry" starring Clint Eastwood you get a feel what North Beach was like back then. Throughout the hardened years North Beach has maintained its charm. When Tony Bennett sings his signature song "I Left My Heart In San Francisco" I feel part of the character of San Francisco is North Beach. There are a lot of tourist sites to see in San Francisco such as Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf, and Alcatraz. If you're tired visiting tourist sites unwind by eating Italian regional cuisine and sipping espresso at North Beach.
author: Gerald R.

description:
Believe it or not, North Beach used to be an ACTUAL beach! Eventually the beach underwent land reclamation in order to expand in the late 19th century and has thus gone through a few transformations. 

Destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and subsequent fire, it was rebuilt into what we know as Little Italy. 

Buongiorno! 

Left and right, you'll see Italian cafes, bakeries, restaurants, and little Italian flags painted onto lamp posts throughout the neighborhood. Famous for having the oldest Italian restaurant in America and also associated to such popular names like baseball player, Joe DiMaggio; North Beach truly has a rich history. 

Even home to Coit Tower and Pier 39, this location is a prime area for tourism and amazing food and sightseeing. 

I always have a great time exploring this district. Doesn't hurt that I can always count on scoring a good bowl of pasta either.
author: Ann S.

description:
Great neighborhood!  We somehow missed this part of town the last time we were in San Francisco.  For us, we fit right in.  Great Italian food, lots of interesting local shops (book stores, candy stores, etc) and of course Telegraph Hill and Coit Tower nearby.

We found ourselves coming back to North Beach for just about everything - dining, shopping, tourism.  I would LOVE to live in this neighborhood someday!
author: Johanna K.

description: The best of living in Europe, a west coast metropolitan neighborhood and an oceanside town...that's North Beach.   An eclectic blend of old and new...old world close-knit community and new cool stores (like Cornology!).  Nestled between iconic neighborhoods of Chinatown, Telegraph Hill, Russian Hill, Nob Hill, and the famous SF Wharf...North Beach is a conduit between cultures where you can take the dim sum you got in Chinatown across the street and sit at a parklet on Columbus St and have Italian Illy lattes (the best of Italy and China all in one place!). Where every Italian restaurant has fresh pasta and you can have regional types of pizza all within walking distance. This is the place where the "regulars" say hi and we have an annual parade where the neighbors party next to you and also jump on the floats to dance.  THAT IS North Beach.
author: Mitzi A.

description:
Someone once told me that the most important thing in a neighborhood is community.

This neighborhood is all about that.

This is San Francisco's Little Italy.  You'll hear folks speaking Italian when you're walking around; totally normal.

The cafes know your order, sometimes even before you do.

Twice in the last week alone, someone quietly warned me to zip up my handbag.  I run around w it unzipped all the time.  They were both older ladies, & maybe they were just being maternal.  But how sweet is that?

And, if your demeanor is looking off in any way, it's not surprising for the barista/manager/owner to come over to you & ask, by name, if you're ok.  

Long opposed to big businesses, NB petitioned against Starbucks opening on Columbus Avenue years ago.  

No matter where you stand in this hood, you're right by a cafe, a bakery, a restaurant, or a bar.  Probably all 4.

This is where to find the best cappuccino, the best cannoli, the best red sauce joint, & the best veal saltimbocca in SF.  Followed by pizza, carbonara, & gelato.  Add a picnic in Washington Square Park w a sandwich from Molinari's or Alimento, & a drive up to Coit Tower to take in the view on a clear day or night, & you've done quintessential NB.

That is, after you've had a nightcap at Tosca.  Or Vesuvio's.  Or Specs.  If you want to go all old school, it'll be all 3.

Why do you think all the beatniks made this their home back in the day?

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: My wife and I stopped here after a great comedy show. Since we haven't had dinner yet we were walking around to find an open place and came across this amazing restaurant. We were seated the the staff was very friendly and nice. I ordered the spinach raviolis while she ordered a tiramisu. Everything was wondering including the food. I look forward to coming back again soon and patronizing this business again soon. It was nice to learn that it has been a family own business since the 70's. You don't find that very often anymore in the city.
author: Jeremy M.

description: Had the pleasure to be seated at a square table for 8!  It was a great setting because we all could talk with everyone without having to yell across the room.  The service was great and the food was delicious.  Started off with pasta della casa, salad, & minestrone soup...tasty! Then we all enjoyed our main courses: mini lobster tails, chicken, pasta and Petrale sole.  All were prepared very good and all were very delicious. The only thing that I didn't care for is the vegetable and potatoes that came with the entrees. They were a bit bland.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Like a moth to a...burning shot of whiskey, I am drawn to North Beach every time I am in town.  

Dining, drinks, coffee, people watching, whatever...this is my favorite place to wind up (or wind down) an evening.

You owe it to yourself to spend some time hanging out here...it worked for Kerouac.
author: Jim W.

description:
Parking easy if you use valet.
The servers and the food are "the best" my favorite by far as to Italian food.
author: Carol M.

description: Used to come here on a weekly basis with or without friends. Being half Italian, I craved those flavors I tasted at my dad's home in Northern Italy when I was a kiddo, whenever we came to visit my grannie, aunts & uncles. I came here for the only places that served a legit espresso (Starbucks didn't exist back then), had some Italian style pastries and spoke with the locals, mostly from Tuscany, who would always try to pick on me. Darn, just like in Italy! Could not afford the restaurants back then, I was a humble university student with 2 jobs trying to survive on used clothes from Ashkenazi downtown Berkeley (does it still exist?) & $1 pizza coupons from the university journal. But this area of town felt a bit like my "other home" more than 6k away. Chinatown was already spreading its wings over this barrio, I imagine the only Italian things left now are the usual expensive Italian restaurants. I came back in the early 2000 to visit mother's relatives & friends but spent very little time in this part of SF, so soaked with fond memories for me.
author: Grazia B.

description: Over 17 years ago I discovered this place and have never been disappointed in the food...I don't even live in CA and have eaten there at least a dozen times.   We were in town last week and the food is always great, the atmosphere is wonderful, but what really sets the place apart is the service.  Many of the staff have been there for over 20 years!  Try the carbonara, the amatriciana, any of the antipasto dishes and you'll have a hard time finding room for the wonderful main courses!   Leave room for dessert.
author: Connie O.

description:
I haven't spent a huge amount of time here, but it's a hip an diverse area for all kinds of reasons. My limited perception is that by day it's filled with tourists, and in the evening locals wining and dining. 

It's cool just to walk around, and there's contrast with the waterfront and hilly areas.
author: Peter N.

description: It's an amazing neighborhood filled with character and history.  I love driving down Columbus with the Transamerica Pyramid in full  view the whole way.  Stop for an espresso or a pastry and people watch for the afternoon or do a little research and find a great restaurant to dine at while soaking up the local vibe.  Sotto Mare? This is Little Italy-- San Francisco style.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Love.

Italian food everywhere you turn. Sotto Mare has some of the best Italian seafood I've ever had. Visit Coit Tower with the amazing views of the city. Great wine. Bars, restaurants, GELATO?! ... so many places to visit, and so many foods that I was too full to try :(

I neeeed to come back here the next time I'm in town. It could just be my favorite neighborhood in San Fran!
author: JoAnna D.

description:
I love this Little Italian town in SF!  

The vibe here is so cozy and yet, rowdy when it comes to Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights! 

There are so many great Italian restaurants, pubs, bars and boutiques!

Cafes here are great too!  Getting brunch is a definite must here!  

There is the Washington Square Park, where it is a super nice park to lounge at!

This district also has the dreamy Coit Tower - that makes one of the many iconic monuments for SF!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Mmmm.... Amazing food, impeccable service, great atmosphere.  The seafood is fresh and delectably prepared. Try the Puttanesca my personal favorite. The service us the best in California. It feels like an NYC restaurant. They also have extemporaneous musical guests. What fun!!!!
author: Linda A.

description: Order from the menu or not. We asked Nino for special orders and he delivered. The prosciutto room is amazing. The food is fabulous. The atmosphere is fantastic as is the service. Could not more highly recommend.
author: Patrick P.

description:
What a treat this place was!

We stumbled in here on accident, and boy am I so glad we did. Greeted by amazingly friendly and attentive staff, we were seated promptly.

Our server Mel was an absolute delight. He was warm, kind, and made sure we had everything we needed without hovering or interrupting our dining experience unnecessarily.

The wine selection was great. I ordered the Chicken Scaloppini Piccata - delicious! The sauce was perfectly seasoned and so flavorful. Accompanied by potatoes and greens, it was a great meal overall.

My date ordered the Tortellini Supreme and had nothing but good things to say about it.

Five stars all around!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Pros: 

(+) Cute little neighborhood
(+) Plenty of bars, boutiques, restaurants....
(+) Street fairs
(+) TVs to watch the games

Cons: 

(-) Parking is a nightmare
(-) Our service was slow

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

In the heart of San Francisco. The pizza here is okay. Definitely nothing compared to New York pizza back home but hey...it was good enough. We came here to watch the World Cup while chowing down on some slices. The service here was slow but it was ok given that we were busy watching the World Cup anyways.
author: Arlene F.

description:
Alive with crackling energy, any spot you enter is bound to have characters, good food and a welcoming mentality. It's hard to have a bad time in North Beach. 

Lat night, we went to Rogue Ale House. Got some damn good brew! Took a stroll with an infamous "marijuana cigarette" (reeefer). While our friend was trying to be discreet off an alley, a dude that lives in the park stopped by and declared he needed " A WHIFF OF THAT STIFF" He sniffed emphatically. Cajoling "You gotta exhale sometime man," he chatted for 5 minutes. Gems like, "Hey man, you look liked Dennis Leary. Yeah, like a comedian. A low-key comedian." At the end of the chat, we got a "Love you guys" and off he went. haha! All this, natch, took place 2 feet from where people were trying to enjoy their dinners. 

The Saloon is the best bar in town. You walk in and it's like they're glad to see ya. Pull up a stool or get out and dance. 

Golden Boy Pizza finished up the night for us. The iconic design just gives an energy that you don't find elsewhere.
author: Em L.

description: I love that in San Francisco you are in the thick of screaming grandmothers throwing pieces of bok choy at each other, and then you walk two blocks and you get Italian grandfathers having a loud argument about bocce while slurping from a tiny espresso cup.  Welcome to North Beach.  My favorite part of North Beach are the gorgeous trees that line certain streets - not sure what they are, but they add such a wonderful "neighborhood" feel.  So many places to eat and drink, convenient to some of the more famous places like the Embarcadero, Fisherman's Wharf, etc.
author: Allie A.

description: Excellent. The service alone makes this a 5 star restaurant. There isn't a better Italian place in SF.
author: Andy M.

description:
4 stars verging on 5 during the day. A nice little neighborhood with character and fascinating history that's been preserved fairly well, heaps of great restaurants, amazing views if you venture up the steep hills, and you can wander over to Chinatown and the wharfs right next door too. You pay a bit of a premium for the food here, but really not much more than anywhere else in expensive-ass SF. 

1 star verging on 0 at night / on weekends. Place turns into Loser Nexus mostly centered on Broadway and Columbus where all the titty clubs and dive bars are, though it spills out to some degree everywhere that isn't a real steep walk up a hill. Drunk bums, drunk frat boys, drunk stupid club girls, East Bay gangbangers, low-level pimps, just basically every shithead within a 20 mile radius gravitates here for their stupid peasant debauchery and penny-ante street criminality. And most of the good food places close up shop shortly after this shitfest begins in earnest, most of the food available late night / early morning is garbage. 

Seriously might be the most Jekyll and Hyde neighborhood in the world from night to day
author: Jeremy H.

description: I absolutely love this neighborhood.  Little Italy, Chinatown, Russian Hill are all nearby.  Washington Park is here.  The Chinatown Y & the library.  I can go on and on....
author: Michael L.

description:
Definitely my favorite neighborhood in San Francisco. There's nothing like being in North Beach in the morning, when the neighborhood is waking up, and the tiny groceries are getting their delivieries, and early birds are sipping their coffee, reading their papers while sitting at bistro tables. 

The place is clean, fun and full of life. It's so quaint, it's like... it's like that place you've always wanted to live. It's cozy, walkable and beautiful. There's Catholic churches everywhere, bustling cafes and little boutiques. There are spacious parks to sit and eat lunch and a spectacular view. It seems like the only area in the City that I'd want to raise a kid (if I had to.)

Definitely walk Columbus end to end - you'll love what you find.
author: Rachel S.

description:
North Beach is adjacent to Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf, Telegraph Hill, and Russian Hill, all of which have been on my walking (and eating) routes as I've explored this City by the Bay for years. And when the old Embarcadero Freeway was up (before the 1989 Loma Prieta Earthquake), the on ramp was just down Broadway and I loved the quiet here as I headed off to work. I also enjoyed the variety of activities available within a few short blocks and the neighbourhood's Peter and Paul anchor with their living room park in front. And then there's the opera singing at Cafe Trieste.... 

The neighborhood is San Francisco's Little Italy and still has the associated restaurants, pastry, and culture, especially along Columbus and Grant Avenues and Washington Square. The beatnik culture (with an assist from City Lights Books) started here and the red light and other nightlife areas are close at hand. So is the young professional and Chinatown expansion that has compacted the Italian flavour.

The area largely known today as North Beach was an actual beach, filled in with landfill around the late 19th century. Warehouses, fishing wharves, and docks were then built on the newly formed shoreline. Due to the proximity of the docks, the half of the neighborhood south of Broadway was home of the infamous Barbary Coast.

Following its reconstruction after the 1906 Earthquake, the proximity of the nearby docks and fishing wharves attracted a large amount of Italian immigrants that would create the Italian character of the neighborhood that exists to this day. And due its past legacy as the Barbary Coast, Broadway east of Columbus, grew to be the home of the city's red light district and striptease clubs.
author: Eric B.

description:
It once was a beach!

Then along came a big landfill initiative that transformed this shoreline further outward.

It's certainly great neighborhood worthy of your time to explore. What will you see? A diverse population and a home to some great restaurants, bars, cafes, and architecture. 

Please never change.
author: Derek N.

description:
I was looking for some delicious Italian food in a cozy restaurant with servers who barely speak English. North Beach was close enough for me. The food was fantastic and the service was very good. 

I had the prosciutto and melon to start and the tagliatelle bolognese. They make their own cured meats in house, and it was delicious. The bolognese was the best I've had in a long time. It was the perfect sized portion, not too big, just enough to fill me up. 

The service was pretty good, at this point in my day I was pretty tired and it seemed we had to wait for the server a little too long a few times. That could just have been me being whiny though (it happens). 

If I'm ever in San Francisco again and in need of Italian food I'd stop by North Beach again.
author: Kate M.

description: So this is the Italian area of San Fran?  Or at least that's the vibe I'm getting.  Or you can say it's the area between all the other places who's names are more obvious (i.e. Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf, etc).  It seems like a pretty neat place with shops, restaurants, bars and more.
author: Alan S.

description: North Beach feels like dining with family in an upscale environment.  We invariably wind up ordering the Sole Meunire, even though there are lots of other tempting entries on the menu. Consistently wonderful.
author: Tom H.

description:
Yes, we are far and few between. I was born and raised in this place we call North Beach. I went to Jean Parker, the prison in the Marina, and Hatchet High. Then to Harvard on the Hill. If you know these places, then you know North Beach and San Francisco. 

When I was about 7 we used to ride plastic mats down Vallejo Street. When I was about 10 we moved up and rode Big Wheels down the hill. 

I was here celebrating on Columbus Avenue when the 49ers won their first Super Bowl in 1981 and again when the Giants won their first World Series in 2010. 

My uncle used to own a butcher shop that was next to the left side of Walgreens. I used to go down there and ask for a hot dog. Yeah I ate it uncooked. 

I remember when there was a Woolworth's across the street from Walgreens. Got busted when I was 7 stealing a hot wheel. That sucked.

Before Molinari Delicatessen, there was Panelli Brothers. Panelli Brothers was located where the Adidas shoe store is on Stockton. I used to get a salami sandwich on white with mustard and mayo. Oh yum.

Yeah...needless to say, good times...North Beach is my home and it will always be no matter where I go. As the saying goes, "I left my heart in San Francisco..."
author: William M.

description: Italian food everywhere you turn. Visit Coit Tower with the amazing views of the city. Great wine.
author: Gavin M.

description: Great neighborhood, I made lots of friends over there.andwe hangout at pier the park and the 2nd building
author: Uzma S.

description: I love North Beach - and all the Italian (and other) restaurants an shops.  A great neighborhood for locals and tourists. (The locals know which places to avoid).
author: Karen F.

description: came here with my family and just walked around. While walking around the neighborhood, it just felt so nice. The environment and energy was so calm and serene. I love San Francisco!
author: Zochi F.

description: Someone told me to go here for the go-go bars and all I can remember is agreeing to go to a back room with two girls who were about to suck me dry until the bouncer gave my an out and I took it. Good looking out. Saved me $500 bucks and regret in the morning. San Fran is a cool town, but the California law that doesn't permit alcohol in nude bars is dumb. Make sure to go down to the pier and see Lombard street.
author: Steve S.

description: This is a traditional Italian restaurant. I have been here more than 10 times and every dish is always done to perfection. They are very accommodating to any changes that you want to make to any dish. A few favorites of mine are veal Milanese, traditional lasagna and fettuccini  with Alfredo and salmon steak. The staff is always very charming and they go out of their way to make sure my toddler is happy. Wonderful place.
author: M Z.

description:
I give it a ((("S" x 3!!!)))

So......

Scrumpti-ta-ly......Scan-ti-ta-ly.....Scrump-ti-OOOO-cious!

Everything was ((("S" x 3!!!)))

From the individualized caprese salad with a side of prosciutto laying over sweet cantaloupe...

I had the Fish Portofino, stuffed with mussel and shrimp. 

Scrumpti-ta-ly......Scan-ti-ta-ly.....Scrump-ti-OOOO-cious!
author: Jennifer C. L.

description: Charming neighborhood. Not simply because it is "North" and has good connotations because of your North Face jacket or any such thing. Wide array of restaurants, places for coffee, it's an interesting walk and good for people watching as well. I mostly just strolled through and kept on going since it was too recent in time to eat again, and not late enough in the evening that it was what is colloquially referred to as "Beer O'Clock."
author: Daniel L.

description:
North Beach is one of the most famous neighborhoods of San Francisco.  It's where you'll find some of the best Italian food that the West Coast has to offer!!  Lots of great restaurants and cafes and some great scenery to be found here.  It's very close to SF icons like the Transamerica Pyramid and Coit Tower, and right next door to Chinatown.

The only downside is that I've never been able to find any parking anytime I'm in North Beach...
author: Chris Y.

description:
The quintessential San Francisco neighborhood.  It's jam-packed on weekends, which makes it very annoying.  Tourists and locals and tourist-locals and local tourists and Aaron Peskin-types populate the place.  As with nearby Chinatown, many of the people who live here never leave here.  I always find this funny.

I love North Beach almost as much as I love City Lights.  Scratch that.  I love City Lights truly.  I love North Beach because of City Lights.  Or at least that's about 47 percent of the reason I love North Beach.  I always get suckered into coming here on a weekend with out-of-towners, and that bothers me, and then I don't come here for months because of this, and that's a shame.  I should come on a Tuesday night.  I will, in fact, once the spring semester ends.

People need to love this city.  Enough people love this neighborhood, but I encourage all of them to love this city.  That's North Beach's problem, really:  Its residents love their neighborhood more than they love their city.  I can understand this.  I think at one point I loved my neighborhood more than I loved San Francisco.  But then I realized my neighborhood was a lie, or that I had been on the wrong side of a poorly argued argument.  Don't get me wrong; I love my neighborhood.  But some of its residents?  Hm.

People named Alberto want to live in North Beach.  In another time, as a different person, I would want to live in North Beach.  If you gave me a cheapish rent-controlled apartment with a tomato-sauce can turned into a WiFi antenna--no joke, a North Beach resident I knew did this, and it worked!--I might just take it.  Because there's a cafe culture, if not a coffeehouse culture.

It's everything the Mission and 9th & Irving and Clement Street want to be but aren't.  It's important in life to be good at being yourself, not at trying to be or lamenting not being other people.  So, North Beach, keep getting on with your bad self.  But remember that there are people who live all over this city who love you.  We really do.  We can abide awkward sibling-birthday-party arguments and good pizza chains that serve mediocre pizza when you export them to other neighborhoods and even Mona Lisa, but we can't put up with self-importance.  You're important, but you're not that important.

Hopefully, the Big One will liquefy the Marina and Fisherman's Wharf (with no casualties), and then you'll once again have an honest-to-goodness beach.  But until then, I'll keep loving you even though you don't know I exist.
author: John S.

description: North Beach is the new food wasteland of San Francisco. The many bland tacky restaurants I will leave to the tourists. Tacos, pasta, Chinese food---none of which authentic. The endless construction is irritating. The lack parking is stomach-turning. A walk around Washington Square might be enjoyable. I'll by all means stay away from the restaurants.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I wish I had lived in North Beach while I was taking Italian for two years in college. Sadly, I live in Houston, where NO ONE speaks the language. I had to settle for the occasional Italian magazine I would stumble upon, or sometimes things like the Italian version of Wikipedia, but I digress. Suffice to say, part of San Francisco that I love so much is that even coming from a diverse city such as Houston, it is so wonderful to hear so many languages spoken on the street, but I especially love hearing the Italian language in North Beach. 

On my last trip to San Fran, we stayed in North Beach -- went to a couple neighborhood bars, walked to City Lights Books, walked to the Wharf and to Chinatown, and even the Financial District. What a great location!

Other things I love about North Beach:
-the Italian food
-the Italian pastries
-the little neighborhood coffee shops
-the small-town feel
-Katsu! (see my review if interested)

The Verdict: Wish I could be taking a walk in North Beach right now.
author: Cara S.

description: I have been coming here for over 25 years and I still consider it my favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco. The food is amazing and very consistent. The Fish dishes are great so are the pastas and the Veal. I have entertained many clients over the years and continue coming back for business and with my wife and kids. As a past restaurant owner in San Francisco I appreciate classics and this is definitely a classic.
author: Louis M.

description:
North Beach is one of the neighborhoods in San Francisco that I enjoy the most. I am not talking about the tourist main drag.  I am talking about the shops located off the beaten path.  Your mom and pop butcher store, bakery, pizza shop and friendly people. 

Of course you can go and have some food at the Stinkin' Rose, but if you are a tourist... do yourself a favor and just walk into one of the smaller no frills places located in the area and that is where you will find some good food.
author: Amelia M.

description: Love walking around here... all of the carbs and sweet goodies you cannot go wrong. I consider getting a cannoli a must. I love the smells and small cafes....
author: Vicky T.

description: used to live in this area but liked it a lot. its riht there outside of chinatown and in the middle of little italy. Always very lively and got a lot going on. if you walk a little further, you reach fisherman's wharf. there is also usually a small farmer's market and art displacys going on. one downside is a lot of tourists come to this area needless to say so the main streets get crowded
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
North Beach, oh how I have a love-hate relationship with you. I live off Grant on a side street and although my roommate and I are slightly hidden away from the madness, everyone and their mother can hear the drunken escapades just blocks away.

It's rather interesting to try to explain to your parents what area of town you live in. It's not like I can hide the fact that strip clubs are literally in my backyard... the neon signs and half naked girls on posters give it away. But the area does have its perks...I do enjoy being able to walk to work each day and have so many options of cafes to purchase my morning coffee. Everyone knows the parking sucks but the views from our apartment are breathtaking (see pics) and I'm pleased with the solid selection of restaurant, bars and a decent park nearby.
author: Lan H.

description:
I love this neighborhood. It's a nice "get-away" from the main hustle and bustle that is S.F. This is another neighborhood that I wished was in Los Angeles. 

The numerous cafes, stores, parks, and the entire ambiance reminds me of something I would find in Central Park. I really enjoyed the walk around here after eating breakfast. You can see the Bay/Alcatraz and take in your surroundings and just let your mind wander. 

There was a festival of sorts (or just a bunch of people) at the park and it looked like they were flying kites. It looked like a picture out of a movie or a  t.v. show. This is a perfect spot to take a date and just walk around and spend some quality time, let time slowly pass you.
author: Wes S.

description:
I was turned onto Christopher Moore's books and loved seeing North Beach spots referenced by characters like Abby Normal, Charlie Asher and Tommy Flood.    

Also, whether it's been Stella cafe, Rogue or Coit Tower, I've had a great time eating and drinking North Beach. 

NB is one of many SF neighborhoods of unique histories and character that I enjoy learning about while exploring.
author: Darren S.

description: Not really anything bad to say.  Its a Historic site of Italian History, and some of the businesses are still around, and its good to see lots of Pizza and restaurants available.  Just about anyplace that you pick will be good.
author: Rob L.

description: Wonderful all the way around, food, service, ambience. Prosciutto, risotto, pasta, sautéed sole, halibut. Wow!
author: Paul T.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, so i suppose i'm a little bias, but it's pretty great. 
Fun restaurants, great cafes, nice parks, convenient and very walkable. It's fun to explore. 

Tips:
- The House restaurant
- Tony's Pizza
- Golden Boy Pizza
- DeLise Cafe
- Blue Sparrow Pilates
- Lola
- Vietnam Cafe
- Tuk Tuk Cafe
- Trader Joe's
- Cafe Divine
- Naia Gelato
- Goorin Brother's
- Washington Square Park
- Coit Tower
- City Lights Bookstore

I'm glad i live here!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
The stars doesn't mean the place/area is bad. It was some kind of block party sometime ago and I did find it quite nice/fun. This neighborhood has a ton of restaurants and a few bars I noticed. 

When I went it was quite fun,but again check out the restaurant's in the area. 

My 3 stars doesn't mean it is bad,but I would suggest this place to some people.
author: Dani D.

description: Their coffee shops are delicious, but it seems that all they had there was just that-cafés and restaurants. After I ate I didn't feel like there was a whole lot to see. We saw the cathedral, which was lovely, and there's Coit Tower (which I didn't go on) but that's about it  if you're going as a family. The streets are lovely but I didn't find there to be many things to do, I would have liked to experience more Italian culture like you experience Chinese at Chinatown and Japanese at Japantown.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I had a business dinner here last night.  I ordered the polenta soup and veal cutlet parmigana.  The polenta soup was just fucking-awesome..full of flavor and so tasty.

The veal cutlet was good, nothing special, but very satisfying.  

Great place for Italian food and people watching.
author: Raider J.

description:
This place is great if you are under 30 and like to party. Or, if you are over 30 and don't like to party, but like diverse restaurant choices. 

North Beach is a tourist area that is not quite so blatant as Pier 39. The nudie clubs are a magnet for the drunken or soon to be drunken revelers. These clubs have touts standing in the doorway asking if you would like to see naked women. I would get it daily walking from BART up Columbus to my place past Washington Park. There are tour buses, double-deck buses, horse drawn carriages, mini-rental microkarts, and limos bringing the tourists for a look-see of all the Points-Of-Interest in the North Beach Area. 

Parking is a joke, and sometimes coming home from work on a Saturday night, it would take me a half hour or more to find a parking spot. The air is particularly dirty here, as I found out when I left my front apartment window open one night because of the heat. The next morning there was soot spotted all over my window sill, and it had come in on the white runner I had on my dresser.  

From North Beach your are within walking distance to Trader Joe's, Safeway, the aforementioned Pier 39, and to the Financial District. It is a good place to live if you do not have kids.

I would like to find some historic maps of San Francisco to see if in the old days the Bay was nearer to this neighborhood, and maybe the beach part of North Beach used to be real.
author: Jimbob P.

description:
I love North Beach! 

I just wish it wasn't such a pain in the ass to get to.
author: Murphy O.

description:
If you come to the neighborhood for a movie at Washington Square Park (or for any other reason), please pick up your shit! Those of us who live here are tired of picking up after you! We are especially tiered of trying to take our dogs to the park  to play, and have to end up chasing them around  because people decided to throw all their leftover food on the ground. Have some common sense and common courtesy, there are people who actually live in this neighborhood. We are not all on vacation.  

P.S. Doorways are not your personal place to puke / shit / piss after you partied to hard and have no control over your bodily functions. At least make it to the street..... Then go home!
author: Julia S.

description:
I love NoBe! 

Next to the Mission, NoBe is the place to be! North Beach coined as Little Italy in SF are blocks of honest to goodness restaurants, bars, shopping gems, cafes, bakeries, and parks.
author: Mika D.

description: I hope to get my first apartment here! I'm new to SF this year, and i've been alot of places. But this is the most beautiful, clean, and diverse neighborhood in SF by far. Northpoint is the untouristy side of the Wharf. This place is my true love, and i hope to live here in the next 2 years! I wouldn't say it's the most amazing tourist spot, no homless people around here for a reason- but it's the most amazing place to live. Anyone who thinks the Haight is the best part of SF, doesn't know SF. Right by the water and afew beautifully grassy parks, an entire Little Italy area, Chinatown, and so much more- this place is beyond unique and jampacked with random places. Reminds me of Westwood in Hollywood back home, but on some major steroids. I hope to call this place my home in the near future ^.^
author: Brittainie B.

description: My favorite part of the city for dining, especially the Italian Restaurants.  We attended the Festival a couple of weeks ago too and it was fun.  There was a lot of excellent music from single violin players to awesome bands including a latin one that played some great Santana & Salsa.  I come here all the time, LOVE North Beach!
author: Ruthie V.

description:
Love this place! Mel the Maitre D is wonderful. Makes you feel at home.  Always gives samples of the House Sangiovese, mmmmm.  

Samy G the bartender is absolutely amazing. Such a handsome man too! Eye candy is always a good thing :)

Definitely a tourist spot but if you want to impress a date with an old school authentic Italian vibe, this is definitely the spot. 

My favorites are the Lasagna (hand made) and anything with Veal. The white sauce is absolutely decadent but worth every caloric bite.

Samy makes me a really good cocktail with champaigne and chambord. Dee-lish!

Definitely will come back again and again like I already do
author: Annette M.

description:
I lived in North Beach for a few months. I really loved it. Minus the car being towed and living with all boys who partied on weekdays until wee hours in the morning. We had an awesome roof with an amazing view of the city. We even had a huge party once. Parking was almost impossible but somehow I made it work. I remember having to get up early to move my car from Coit Tower.. let me tell you those hills are the best work out! Buns of steel baby! 

You really can't bash on the tourist either. Come on people this is SF.. we're all transplants here. My girlfriends and I have lived here for a while and we are stilling planning to have a day to ride around on the double deck-er bus and shwill some drank. Shh don't tell. 

Overall North Beach is one of my favorite spots in the city to eat, drink, shop or even just walk around. 

Just a note: If you don't like tourist don't live in the f-ing city!
author: Danielle K.

description:
I love North Beach so much it makes me wish I were Italian.

Naia. Golden Boy. North Star. Tuk Tuk Thai. Those are some of the reasons why I love to go to North Beach, plus the atmosphere. Whether day or night, you will always find a chill crowd out to have a great time. I love that it is walking distance from my apt in Nob Hill, or a short bus trip on the 30 or 45 from work.
author: Natalie S.

description: Great wine selection! Stags leap cast 23 is Delish
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I grew up in NB, on Filbert, but moved at 9 but was back weekly to my great aunt's house or grandma's.  I remember all the good times, the carnival Sts. p&p used to have in the Washington park, panelli's (my sister's went to school with them) the boy's club, etc.  I still love to go back, and do, whenever I can.  To this day, sometimes when walking thousands of miles away, i can smell something, no doubt some sort of bakery smell, that takes me back to 1972 on Columbus and Stockton with my dad on xmas day going to the 5 and dime to buy batteries for my new toy.

The stores may change, there my be urine in the street (there always was, DUH!) but it is, and always will be, my home away from home.  NB forever.

Ya feel me??
author: Johnny L.

description:
Here is another of the old Italian Restaurants in the city. We have been there a few times. 5 stars also for the no hassle valet parking. 
The food here is exquisite. I especially like the sand dabs when in season. They really know how to make them to perfection. The pasta dishes along with the wine selection are worth going back for anytime.
Triple thumbs up here also
author: Charlie O.

description:
I have lived here for two years now and fell in love with this neighborhood from day 1 when I visited it in college to now, a NB local. My teamname in the World Series of Beer Pong was even Team North Beach. Gotta love grabbing a slice of pizza at Golden Boy then heading over to GnG for dollar PBRs and $3 Fernets. If you want to just relax you can walk to Fisherman's Wharf or Washington Square park. 

As much as I love NB we need to figure out our homeless problem. I know it's a city wide issue but you know it's bad when you see scaffolding on a building and your friend says "that's gonna be bunkbeds for the homeless tonight." What can we/the City do about this?
author: Corey R.

description:
Oh how I enjoy strolling the streets of North Beach. Never will I grow tired of the sardine packed sidewalks, the endless circling of blocks for parking and the sweet aroma of pizza, freshly baked bread and lone musicans creating the soundtrack of North Beach.
The beaming ambiance and soulful beatnik personas make North Beach what is is best for.
author: Mary Ella D.

description:
Way too many assholes, way too many tourists, way too many asshole tourists from stockton yelling at me while i'm trying to eat an Its-It in front of the Grant and Green Market. What's that, 209? You're so fucking wasted dood? What a revelation. You're slightly more tolerable than the "artists" who don't do art and the "poets" who haven't had anything published since high school  hanging out in front of Trieste... day after day after day after day (nice socks with birks, fucko. did kerouac dress like a tool, too?) ... but only slightly. And that's only because I've seen a wild parrot shit on you, and not an artist/poet. Yet.

That being said... there's nowhere with better nightlife, more bars and better food in a smaller area. I mean, 41 bars in less than a square mile?? really??  It's overrun with fuckheads for a reason -- it has all that, and nowhere else in town has a better publicity committee.
author: Chris R.

description: While it's full of yuppies, suburbanites, and other tourists, a night out in North Beach is essential for any visitor.  There are a zillion bars in this historically Italian district and at least as many restaurants. Some restaurants are spectacular, others are mediocre.  The great ones (such as Tommaso's and L'Osteria Del Forno) will require long/possibly intolerable waits.  Drunkenness and Golden Boy Pizza also work well together.
author: Matthew L.

description:
The neighborhood has really gone downhill.  Jane Jacobs wrote about the "unslumming" of North Beach decades ago in her book Death and Life of Great American Cities.  Well the "reslumming" has commenced.

Broadway has been lost for some time now, and all the jazz and music clubs from the old days are now either strip clubs, adult book stores, or tacky "bar/club/restaurants".  Five of my friends have been mugged in North Beach this past year alone.

NB has lost most of its character, and has become the public urinal for the B&T crowd on the weekends and a bastion of overpriced mediocre Italian cuisine for tourists.  There are only one or two places I go to in North Beach, but I'm like Maggie D. now...

I visit, then leave.
author: Justin C.

description:
Molto bene.

For my 200th, on this historic day, it's...NB. North Beach-once an actual beach along the coastline of San Francisco, now a thriving & walkable neighborhood with amazing Italian food & wares to old timers to beau-ti-ful weather, you rock & roll.   

My life long home base, you've gotten a serious face lift, darling.  Many mom & pops have folded to more upscale & slightly pretentious places.   Remember Rossi Market,  Panelli's, The Golden Spike?  Remember when there was available parking and only 1 local garage? Ah, the good ol' days.

However, the heart of you is still here.  The annual NB Fair brings out Italian flair with pizza tossing & chalk drawings.  The Columbus Day parade now collides with the noisy Blue Angels.  Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store, NB Pizza, Enrico's, Stella's Pastries & a whole bunch more are still part of the old school regalia. 

And some of the new school fits in-Naia Gelato, Rose Pistola & even more eclectic fares like the House & Brioche have changed NB to become more...worldly.  Even Film in the Park shows at Washington Square  occasionally during the foggy summers.

Just a few steps outside my door, a world of favorites awaits. Thanks, NB.

50 million stars if I could.
author: Jen L.

description:
North Beach..., it's like a small little community where people know each other and you can walk down the street and say hello to your neighbors. Where there aren't that many children but lots of dogs and puppies. A place where you can actually get to know the cops patrolling the beat and say "how's it going?" A neighborhood with a bar for anyone or any mood. The place I call home.
Even though parking's a bitch, even though we get invaded every weekend by a bunch hoodlums who pee in our alleys,.... North Beach is the best place to live.


Doggie Friendliness Meter: EXCELLENT
author: Carla P.

description:
To me, North Beach is the Marina's 1/2 Italian cousin.  Yeah, I know, San Francisco is one big tourist trap, and when I say tourist trap I mean huge source of revenue for the city and small businesses, but North Beach is a bit overbearing for me as a local.  

Pros: 
-Accessible
-Lots of Italians/Italian restaurants
-Washington Square Park (and all the people in it)
-Sidewalk shows

Cons:
-Tourists that stop suddenly and stand in the middle of the sidewalk
-Noise

Overall, North Beach is a cool spot with decent pubs and a bustling nightlife.  I'd go there with friends, but I wouldn't be planning an evening there on my own accord....well, unless we were going to E'Tutto Qua or Steps of Rome.  I love those places (and the sweet Italian men who work there).
author: Jenn T.

description:
Phooey to all the nay sayers!  

Don't be haters.  Tourists are critical and they keep any city alive - don't hate them, definitely don't hate the places they frequent.  Aren't we all tourists to other places?  

North Beach is essentially Little Italy or Italian Town or whatever other states call them.  We are SO LUCKY to have this gem in the heart of SF.  It's so concentrated, so vibrant and just spilling with energy.  

There are so many restaurants, bars, and pubs - no, they are not all fantastic but name one place that has just 5 stars restaurants?  There are some nice boutiques and unique shops.  The bakeries and cafes are true gems.  The locals are the heart and soul that keep it beating...
author: Gloria H.

description:
North Beach is the BEST neighborhood in this entire city.

Your beautiful cafes, the international flavor, your delicious restaurants, the fact that the entire neighborhood shuts down during futbol games, best looking men in town.

World Cup 2006!!!
author: Claudia B.

description: the little Italy of SF, enchanting ... visit from far and wide ...
author: Andrea M.

description: I like the flavor I like the feel. but many of the restaurants are WAY overpriced. I once had a small flat pizza for $20 omg are you kidding me. I felt so gypped. other than that, there are small eateries and specialty shops to browse. cupcakes too. there's a nice park, relaxing on a sunny day. but there's a lot of people and homeless walking around too
author: Veranna N.

description:
Sooo many restaurants and bars that I want to eat and drink at.

i love walking through this hood.  I wish I lived or worked here.

thanks for being so cool.
author: desiree n.

description:
This is my favorite neighborhood ever. Ever! I *love* living here. If I could date North Beach, I would.

Where to start? The food is amazing. The espresso can't be beat. The desserts are perfect as is the weather.  I love the easy access to Trader Joe's. And the views.. from Telegraph Hill to Lombard. I look forward to my daily commute along The Embarcadero.

And why nobody ever told me Italians were so nice and sooo good looking? I said goddamn!
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Loved this neighborhood to death.  I lived here for 16 years before my family and I got split up because of a shady landlord.  This neighborhood has been so good to me.  Great weather. lots of great restaurants and bakeries, fabulous cafes. transportation accessible, great festivals and people are genuinely very nice here.  

I never had a problem with my neighbors....well except that one time for Fourth of July that one year when we went up to the roof to watch the fireworks with my little bro and sis and our next door neighbor decided to go totally butt naked in the kitchen,  he was this muscular Italian guy and it appears about what they say about guys with big muscles....they need to compensate for something.    Needless to say my brother and I quickly cover our sister's eyes and quickly headed down one flight of stairs so we wouldn't see anymore of it.   We couldn't look at him any more without snickering.

How I miss you North Beach, I will return one day very soon.
author: Chris C.

description:
For my 300th Review... it has to be the best neighborhood in San Francisco to LIVE and DRINK in... North Beach!

The 5 Reasons Why:
   1.  Great BARS with friendly bartenders (Columbus Cafe with 2-1 beer happy hour special; Gino and Carlo with Blue Moon on-tap; Vesuvio opening at 6am!)
   2.  Conveniently located and can be accessed by walking, cab, and buses (9X, 30, 45) from downtown.  
   3.  Awesome VIEWS (Coit Tower, the bay, crooked Lombard Street)
   4.  Wide variety of FOOD to choose from other than Italian (Thai, Sushi, Asian-Fusion, seafood)
   5.  Nice CROWD (a good mixed of tourist, locals and people who drink).

I've only lived here for over a year and I don't see myself moving out anytime soon -- I just can't imagine living anywhere else... not yet.  

Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow... North Beach is the BEST :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
I love living in North Beach.  It has some of the best cafes, restaurants and bars in the city!  The overall vibe is very Euro, local and laid back.  Anyone who has ever lived in Europe  will appreciate the highly sophisticated yet imperfect character similar to a small Euro metropolis.  Italian men crowd about Cafe Trieste, cat calling while managing their family business.  Local boutiques carry unique designs and bakeries smell like fresh bread if you get to them early in the morning.  The store facades seem to overlap in a clumsy but deliberate manner down Grant street.  The residents are fairly international, and range from graduated sorority girls to professionals, to young international families.  

As far as the notion that North Beach is "scary"...ummm...you need to get out more.  Yes, the Broadway strip joints are not my favorite part of the area, but hell...they cheapen the rent.  If your idea of scary is North Beach, try visiting a country who's GDP is under 500.

Overall, I'd say North Beach offers one of the best living experiences in the city.  Great crowd, great businesses, great location...the one downfall is that parking is horrendously difficult.
author: Kayti S.

description:
I have made it a point to give out very few 5 stars because that's the highest compliment I can give here. And it's hard to give out a 5 star rating. But when it comes to my old neighborhood, I can't help but cave in. It deserves more than just 5 stars. Much more...

The North Beach vibe is very laid back. You walk around the neighborhood and you can get a feeling of at ease, like time is slowing down just in that part of the City. Slow enough where people seem to mellow out more than others. I miss that...The Sunset is nice but not the same as my North Beach. The ease of life there. How easy it is to find great food and people. Nightlife and the risque scene all meld into one. Just becareful where you go...

And the weather...How can you beat the weather? Never too hot like in some parts and the fog that rolls in isn't all that thick. Once in a while it's hot and maybe thick on the fog but the weather is just right most of the time.

Man, I wish I could move back...
author: Anthony L.

description:
North Beach is one of my favorite, if not my absolute favorite SF neighborhood. I hope to live there someday.

Much of the city is steeped in history, with new neighborhoods cropping up all the time. But North Beach still captures something special. You know when you've entered it and when you have left, it is unlike any other part of the city and at times can feel like its own little world, separate from the rest of SF. 

It's quaint and welcoming, the perfectly charming sort of neighborhood to stroll through on a sunny day. There are lots of cute boutiques and funky shops alike as well Italian cafes and restaurants. It's filled with all sorts of people. You'll see the same old drunken guys sitting on fold out chairs outside of a liquor store, the same platinum blonde new-mommies, the same homeless people, the same elderly doing tai chi at the crack of dawn, the same young people enjoying their Italian food, the same Italian hosts trying to lure you into their restaurant with "Bella, bella, bella..."

At night, North Beach really comes alive. Sure, on Broadway there are some sleezy strip clubs and what not, but North Beach is a really fun place to go for drinks, dancing, dinner, whatever. What I love is that North Beach is so many things at once, comprised of so many different types of people it is impossible to stereotype. You can be a lively bar-hopper or a family playing with the dogs at the park. 

Something about the charm of North Beach has me completely enamored. I love this neighborhood so much.
author: Sophie D.

description:
As long as I avoid coming here on Sunday or Monday, I can obtain:
1. liguria bakery foccacia
2. coppa & prosciutto di parma from Molinari's
3. pastries & espresso from Mara's
4. crab salad from Palermo Delicatessen
5. amaretti & half-chocolate heart cookies from Victoria Bakery
6. a good meal and bottle of wine from Osteria del Forno

And that makes me a happy girl.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I was so looking forward to dining here.  I'd heard so many great things.  Alas, that was not the case in terms of fare.
Although the decor is quite old school (I felt as if I had stepped into a vintage movie set, circa 1960) I thought the food must be great, given what I had heard.  Not so.  So very predictable, what you would expect from a very old restaurant...  Pretty bland, simply seasoned food.  Which in itself is not bad, but given the prices...  Not appropriate.
A good friend dines there when her parents are in town.  They love that place and it certainly has a following.  It's just not where I would choose to go given there are so many other great restaurants in SF for the same or less money.
author: Kara H.

description:
my city, my town, my current place of residence, and my dream come true.  

If you speak english, you'll get by though I reccomend learning at least 3 other languages to truly experience the subcultures.  you'll need:

1. Italian- Prego! Ciao Bella! spanakopitamiliaci! ok that last one was made up, but you get the picture.  You can't possibly walk through northbeach without hearing some italian spewing out... don't worry they aren't yelling AT you... it's WITH you.  especially helpful at pantarei, Danilo cafe and other local italian owned places.

2. Chinese - no examples of the language, but again, walk around and you'll hear it.  Probably don't need to know this one, but if you do you're probably paying 50% less than everybody else.  In this case, they ARE yelling at you. Beware.

3. English - F!@$K you, Asshole, etc.  REally if you can swear in english, that's all you need.  If not, just get drunk at gino & carlos or grant and green and stumble around.   If you slur your words enough and smile, everyone will assume you're friendly.

God I love this place.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Had dinner there once with a bunch of friends & the service was nice and pleasant. We sat in the downstairs area where there were wine bottles all along once side of the wall.
Nice decor and the price is agreeable. The only problem is parking!
author: Mashimaro M.

description: still in the process of trying all the restaurants in this area... parking is usually a hassle.. but what great place isn't?
author: April C.

description: Love my new hood. Best of the city for ratio of bars, restaurants, and sights.
